author: Brandon Harrell
description:
I have to say I love Go because I feel Go literally saved my career.  In 2016 I left Comcast where I strived for several years.  Had I stayed I would have had an amazing data engineering career.  But I decided to move into DevOps.  And that is where I found and picked up Go.  

But what Go did for me is kind of taught  me about how to rethink programming.  I came up in the Java world.  Java was full of frameworks and ceremony.  And there was a "Java mindset".  You had to take on an abstraction first approach to software design. 

Go didn't do that.  It actively penalized you for an abstract first design.   Go also got me closer to the hardware.  I don't consider Go a low-level language.  Clearly with a GC it can only be so performance.  But it is the lowest level high level language I've seen.  There could be other examples (like Nim), but Go set the standard.

So I've learned how to do things like write buffers, flush my i/o, sync data to disk.  It has also helped me better understand HTTP as a protocol and TCP as well.  Who writes TCP listeners in Java?  You do it all the time in Go, and it's not that hard.

I use to think I was a genius coming up with all of these crazy abstract patterns in my Python and Java life.  But now l know less is more.  When I go on projects and I see Go-Java or Go-Python or even Go-Haskell (yeah I've seen this before) from developers who left a project (and now I need to take over the code base), I just shake my head and remember this was me at one point.

And I like the fact that Go is influencing programming language design.  I've seen new languages like Nim, Zig, Odin, and Rust (it's as simple as it can be for what it's trying to do).  And I see the future of software engineering.  I think we can understate how Go is influencing the market.  And I think we have to thank how much it took from C.

#Golang #Clang #nim #rust #softwaredesign #java

Spend some time on implementing a B+ Tree in Zig.  Still on the fence about just doing it in Rust.  But I had to basically roll my own little endian binary encoder, which wasn't too bad honestly.  I probably will have to implement my own writer as well.  Zig does have a library called "readInt" and "writerInt", but I can never get it to work.  Integer casting is annoying, but can't lie.  However bit it exposes me to bit shifting. which honestly I've rarely had to do in my career.  Speaking of which, could Zig be good for IoT especially on the edge?  hmm.

Ok so I actually started to implement my database from scratch last night in Zig.  And well it’s fun.  But zig is only on version 0.12, so it’s in a pre 1.0 release.  That means the standard library is prone to change and I see that things changed drastically from other versions of Zig.  

To create a database I will have to create a MMAP and persist it to disk via fsync which is a syscall.  Like Go there is an attempt to abstract it away.  But as it stands they don’t see to have a fsync implementation for Darwin (which I developed on).  And I don’t want to have to deal with VMs m.

So I think I’m going to decide to implement it in Rust.  While I like Zig more I think Rust has the maturity I need.  Unfortunately I’m dreading dealing with the borrow checker semantics and its ownership model which is confusing. 

Also I have to hand code littleendian in Zig.  Which is fine but the way how unsigned integers work and casting rules is a bit confusing.  Since I would have to declare a u8 then but shift for unsigned int64.

Oh well let the journey begin (again)

#rustlang #zig #ziglang #database

2nd week unemployed, and man what a brutal brutal week.  Every opportunity I had pretty much lead to nowhere.  and I had one of the worst interviewers on the planet.  I'm not playing the blame game, but I've been on enough interviews to know when the interviewer is purposely asking bad questions and trying to trip you up.  Anyway I can't cry over spilled milk.  Just have to hope next week is better.

Anyway this weekend I'm excited to start building my own database from scratch using either Rust or Zig.  I feel it's going to be a lot of fun.  It's a great way to learn new skills.

I know I should be grinding leetcode.  But I find leetcode boring.  And all of the concepts like Trees, List, hashes, and efficient runtimes are all concepts you will deal with in building a database.  Plus it was an interview question, and I'm ashamed I got it wrong because I've been wanting to build a database for years.   This is something I'll be doing in between interviewing and reading rejection emails/DMs lol.

And to my people, because I consider all develpers my people.  Happy weekend, and happy building!

#ziglang #golang #rustlang #rust #zig #database #BTree #BPlusTree #datastructures

To my network.  This unemployment stint (albeit only 2 weeks at this point) has empowered me.  I need to know what are the common AI powered resume scanners or AI recruiting tools.  Are theee usually secrets or serve as the baseline for proprietary software?  I know some AI searches are based on ATS.  Or are ATS things that agencies subscribe to?  I don’t usually market myself as this because I’m not qualified.  But I do have some data science skills and I figured I should put them to work since I got time on my hands

On my timeline I am seeing a lot of developers who are frustrated.  The entire hiring process and the loops that one must jump when dealing with recruiters and hiring managers.  I just wanted to say this, don't give up on this amazing career.  A few years ago the field of software engineering was plentiful.  I remember being unemployed in 2018, and a week later I had like 3 offers.  That was the market back then.  But all markets slow down, and our market is at a crawl.

Me personally, you can reject me 1 million times.  I'm committed to this craft.  I'm dedicated to continuing to learn and level up.  It's what I do, and it's what I do best.  And I believe, no I know I'm a good software engineer. 

We also have to realize that software engineering as a profession is broken.  From the hiring practices, to the project management, and everything in between.  That is why every few years we always have to fix it with things like Agile, Scrum, SaFE, Kanban, etc.  And FAANG has had both a negative and positive impact on the market as whole.

But with that said, always be the change you want to see.  Just because a billion people tell you the sky is green doesn't change the fact that it's blue.  Always do what's right.  Always build and engineer and solution with integrity.  One day the chips will fall, and the house will come crashing down.  Will you be on the right or wrong side of the equation?

Has Golang created a revolution in programming languages?  When Go was created it kind of went against the grain.  It decided to be minimum, steer away from common conventions on OOP and functional programming.  It was verbose in not very expressive.  And it was kind of umm boring.

It was a stark contrast to a lot of the JVM languages that had started to get popular like Scala, Clojure, Groovy, etc.  

Now we are seeing a lot of languages that are doing similar things to Go. Rust obviously shares a lot of similarities in that it decided to move away from classes, leaned more towards composibility, and has value based error handling.  Now we see other languages like Zig and Vlang with a similar strategy.  

I believe for years the systems programming space was settled matter.  You either were a C\C++ developer, or you tried to make it work with Java.  But there was really never anything else.  I’m glad Go gave us a simple but powerful language not seen since C.

I’m very glad I started my Go journey early.  And I’m really excited for the future of programming

#golang #vlang #ziglang #rustlang #java

But Zig has a concept called "allocators", and it has the "defer" keyword.  Very Golang like.

Low level programming is definitely my first love.  Though I think I'm a pretty serviceable backend engineer.

I may actually decide to try to write my "Kafka clone" in this language instead.  I also decided to try to get away from clunky IDEs. And bit the bullet and setup a nevovim environment for myself.

https://ziglang.org/

I think what frustrates a lot of people about job searches is that you're often at the mercy of someone else.  Be that the recruiter, hiring manage, HR personnel, or even the interviewer.  Everything just seems out of your control. It's like you can't take your destiny in your own hand.

Only person you can control is yourself. And the only thing you can really do is level up honestly.  Just show up to an interview, and put yourself in a situation to be the best person they've ever seen.  The best you can do is strive towards being the best

Well had a pretty upsetting rejection today.  Had pretty high hopes but ultimately lead to nothing.  I can put it all on the employers or the interviewer.  But they were more or less pretty good.  So only person I can control is myself.

  The issue is that I didn’t show up to the interview as the best candidate.  The reality is as senior/prinical engineers we are competing with the best of the best.  The level and intellect a senior engineer could know is basically unlimited.

And yes as we’ve enjoyed many years of property and success in our roles.  But maybe that has just lead us to think we’re better than we actually are.  Maybe we’re not good enough because we haven’t had to be good enough due the the past market

With that said I’m definitely not good enough.  Yes there is a lot of stuff I already know.  But there is an infinite amount of things I still have yet to learn.  

I was asked today to build Kafka.  And I was rejected because whatever design I had wasn’t sufficient.  So with that said I’m going to dedicated my time building Kafka.  I am going to study the source code and reimplement it

I could do it in Go but once I understand it I think Go would be too easy.  So I’m going to implement it in Rust.  And I need to get my commit messages up anyway.  Once I have a proof of concept I am just going to open source it

A lot of people may not know this.  But kubernetes has its own garbage collector.  Taking a lot of terminology from Java’s garbage collector like “finalizer”.

  I think this is always a cool concept.  I’ve encountered these problems when deleting a resource thst required a cascading delete creating orphaned resources.  This is definitely behavior that should be understood especially when dealing with controllers.

This article is a great overview.  As a kubernetes developer you’re not super likely to encounter these problems directly.  But it’s nice to understand this behavior in case you do

https://lnkd.in/eY9pF4JQ

#kubernetes #garbagecollectors #kubernetescontrollers

As someone who uprooted himself and moved back to Atlanta to take of his mother.  I made a conscious choice of spending the last year of my mother’s life with her and being there for her instead of going gung ho for a career.  I’m glad I made that decision.

With that said always put the people you love first.  Companies will make a decision about you and it’s not necessarily anything you can take personally.  

However I must say I’ve worked weekends and holidays on problems.  Not because I thought it make me look good.  Or that it was going to give me more money or make my boss like me more.  It is because I genuinely was intrigued by the problem and I had fun solving it. 

And I think that’s an important distinction.  Love what you do.  And find engaging work.  Staying up late building data pipelines, or writing kubernetes operators, or solving Kafka problems wasn’t so my boss could love me.  It was because I found it cool.  And I love learning new things.  

The last thing you want to do is have your boss take you off the cool stuff and do maintenance development.  Maybe this isn’t the most mature post.  But I wouldn’t be in tech if I didn’t think it was cool and fun.

#worklifebalance #technology #kafka #golang

After a long career in tech.  I’ve come to find that the tech market works in cycles.

In the 1950s the tech industry technically began with Fortran as seemingly the first professional language.  And it became so complex that having a deep understanding of of computing became essential to use it.

However business wanted their business people to be able to write their own software.  So they created a business friendly language called COBOL.  But fast forward to the 60s and 70s and COBOL programmers are not only programmers but they are demanding very high salaries.

Fast forward to the 80s and the invention of 4GLs came into tue industry.  These were simple languages (mostly based around basic) with supporting databases.  SAP was a big example of this.  But you have other competitors like dBASE and FoxPro.

Then in the 90s the trend became Rapid Application Development (RAD). You had things like C++ Builder,Delphi, and the kind of them all Visual Basic.  VB being the JavaScript of its era.  

Then we got Web 2.0 and WYSIWG editors.  Now we have low code and no code.  Also AI.

  People are always trying to disrupt the tech industry with something.  But in each of these attempts to do so has only reinforced why you need developers.  Or it has created a new generation of developers and made them even more in demand.

  I’m convinced software engineering will never go away.  But it will continue to evolve with each new paradigm that gets introduced.

#history #ai #4GL

Communicating Sequential Processes or CSP is a concurrent model proposed by Tony Hoare in 1978.  It is also the foundation for concurrency in Golang.  As Rob Pike said this was in inspiration for his model when he created the Go programming language.

I've always known about this paper but I've never tried to read it.  It is an interesting read, and he takes a lot of concepts for Djikstra which I wasn't aware of.  What I really like is the section where he talks about commands and how to compose them to solve issues.

I think the thing here that has the most real world correspondence is his section on monitoring and scheduling.  The Golang scheduler is actually a major thing to understand when it comes to optimizing Golang applications.  

Anyway worth a read.  It's a pretty dry read, but pretty interesting nonetheless.  It uses a lot of BNF notation which is annoying (not a fan).


#golang #concurrency

One of the frustrating of Golang development is that while it has its coding standards, for developers starting out it can be hard to know what idiomatic Go is and what it looks like.  Go really allows you to write complex and unreadable code.  And a lot of times these are valid patterns in other languages.  This leads to a lot of code smells in production code bases.

 A lot of people who work with Go says go should be "simple".  But simple can be very subjective.  One thing I can say I miss about working with Python is PEP8 and a sense of "pythonic" and "non-pythonic".  While not perfect it does give developers a good set of guidelines to what idiomatic code should look like in Python.

Even after 8 years with Go, I'm still not entirely confident about what idiomatic vs non-idiomatic Go looks like.  I have a "sense" of it, but it's hard to say objectively and authoritatively.  I will say there are common patterns and code smells that will often get you in trouble.

A common Golang anti-pattern is interface pollution.  This is more common than you would think.  Especially since many shops move from abstract heavy languages like C# and Java to Go, there can tend to be an over reliance on interfaces.  Also compounded with the fact that many people use interfaces to for mocking means people tend to over rely on them.

  However interfaces can make code unclear.  And it can lead to code indirection.  Especially when there are only single implementations.  You can also introduce potentially a lot of runtime behavior.  Unfortunately a lot of official libraries abuse interfaces.

 Here is an article written by Ardan Labs talking about this.  

https://lnkd.in/edbN8yw4

Configuration management is a make or break for any sort of large scale application.  Getting configuration management wrong can really make adding features to your systems very tedious and error prone.  There is a reason why there have been so many tools designed to attack this problem.

From tools like CFEngine, Puppet, Chef and Kubernetes with configMap, or remote configuration options like ETCD and Consul.  It's also one of my biggest pet peeves.  And something I'm very passionate about

  With that said I just recently discovered Expr-lang.  It was written in Go, and it's an expressive and query language for dynamic configurations.  Definitely plan on using it on some personal (and possibly professional) projects in the near future.  This type of stuff gets me very excited of the possibilities of designing an architecture.  And it seems to be in common use in some very large companies including Google.

A lot of people complain about error handling in Go.  And many have proposed a lot of solutions to deal with it.  But I think people miss the point of error handling in Go.  It’s very explicit.  If you are handling all of your errors as you should, then tracking down errors should be easy.  It creates an easy to follow call stack.  I know it is tedious.  However I will say with tools like co-pilot it’s really not that bad.  

In code reviews never be afraid to call out people who skip errors or complicate them.  Behind some crazy bugs in Go there is always bad error handling

Can’t lie.  2023 really sucked.  I lost my mother who was honestly my best friend.  And career wise I had a few bumps in the road.  I will say I there are some good things at the end of 2023 that I hope materialize in 2024.  I want to do more writing and I definitely want to do more AI projects.  I’m also a huge advocate of neuromorphic computing and IoT so let’s hope to see where the field goes in 2024.  I’m very hopeful.

Golang 1.22 will add an interesting new feature.   This is actually the first breaking change (that I can think of) to the language.  The introduction of loopvar.  Which change the behavior of capturing values in a loop.  This will be an interesting way to write concurrent code, since this is mostly seen in code that uses go routines.  And in effect uses pointers.  This could be a good optimization.  I do like the fact that this was feature flagged, similar to how Go modules was feature flagged back in Go 1.11.

  I think 2024 will be an exciting year for Golang.  I love how uncompromising the Go team is when it comes to the design philosophy of the language.  They aren't just turning it into C# and Java.

The world of LLMs are interesting.  I read the 2017 Paper "Attention is all you need".  And at the time it seemed like a logical progression in the field of NLP.  But I just discovered literally last week that some LLMs allow you to fine-tune them.  Basically create a model of a model.  And then I wondered if I could use an LLM to create a coding model.  And yep there is.  It's called Starcoder.  Which is new to me.  I actually read their paper about how they created the dataset and model.  It's an interesting read.  Only takes about 15 minutes

This paper even has a cool name "May the source be with you".  Nice touch. As someone who loves data engineering I love reading about data curation.

As a distributed systems enthusiast and someone who loves databases.  I often look at B+ tree data structures.  Balanced trees are quite pervasive in the design of database storage.  

  I have been a fan of badgerDB which is a pure Go key value store.  And it uses skiplist instead of the tradition B+ tree or even the more popular LSM Tree.  Anyway I found this article that gives a good comparison of skiplist and balanced trees.  Skiplist are good for concurrent access due to the lack of a rebalancing operation.  Where rebalancing in balanced trees require aggressive locking to avoid any deadlocks

Anyway this paper is a good read.  Highly recommended

Not going to lie.  I’m pretty bullish on neuromorphic computing.  It provides a good alternative to Von Neumann architectures.  And I think it would be very cool if we were able to utilize a synapse based model.   But the question is as a software engineer how do we write software to work with neuromorphic computing?

I think it’s as important area of research as more applications start to target this sort of hardware.  I started reading this paper published last month about NIR (Neuromorphic Intermediate Representation).  What appears to be a unified instruction set for neuromorphic computing.  It’s a very interesting read

I just really started to incorporate the power of generics in my GoLang code.  I used to be against Go getting them because I remember how much more complex it made Java.  But I quite like how much power it gives me from a code design perspective.  I still think it’s usage should be limited to libraries.  Kind of feel like a kid with a new toy.  

  I also think it eliminates the need for “super structs”.  Structs they embed so many types that it creates too much deep nesting.  I can just create an interface and include various struct types. Then constrain them to my functions or other structs.  The modeling flexibility it gives me is pretty nice.  It’s one of the things I’ve always envied from Rust developers

  Anyway I’m having a lot of fun

I’m fortunate to still be in the job market and make an income.

  But I know GoLang at a high level.  Distributed Systems.  Microservice and Event Drive architectures.  Kafka.  A dozen NoSQL databases.

  Consensus protocols like Raft and PBFT.

  Have 10+ years working at Amazon.   Have actually built clouds myself.

  I know OCI, all container technology.

   I feel I study more than I eat.  Or leave the house.  

  And I still feel that I could never keep up in this job market.  Even if could speak to and prove my experience in all the above.

  We have reached an impossible market. 

   Specialization is dead.  You either know everything or you know nothing at all.  In terms of tech roles we are on the verge of technological convergence 

  There will be no seperate roles or jobs.  There will only be one role and one job.  All roles will become one.

   The real question is how do you even keep up?  If I knew the answer to that question I would be a millionaire lol

In 2014 or 2015 I was introduced to elasticsearch.   I absolutely hated it at first.  At this point in my career I was so use to RDBMS systems.  And elasticsearch query system didn’t make a lot of sense to me.  Then I learned about elasticsearch and I learned to love it.  As a matter of fact it is my favorite data store.

Too bad my career journey mostly lead me away from elasticsearch.  I think a lot of concepts in elasticsearch like term vs fuzzy searches.  And N-Gram are so relevant today.  Especially in the world of NLP and LLM.

Elasticsearch was also the first product I used that introduced me to more advanced concepts in distributed systems.  Such as voting for leaders of a cluster.  

Unfortunately elasticsearch is so expensive to run, and is very heavy.  In addition just requiring a lot of specialization to be able to scale its performance.  But it’s a great platform for data geeks like myself.

 I wish there were comparable products written in Go and Rust because I’m still not a fan of the JVM

Everyone is talking about how bad the market is.  But is anyone really surprised.  We’ve been a pattern of hyper growth.  And we’ve thrown way too much capital at way too many things.   

  This was never going to last forever.  Now is the time for real business leaders to make a mark in the market.  I feel there will be many people in need soon, and hopefully those who are creative with principled business minds can step up.

  I thought during the pandemic we would see an explosion in businesses.  But I think the market is correcting and it’s a healthier environment.  

  Of course I think we’re at the start of the AI speculator bubble.  Let’s see how the market shakes out

I don’t make many personal post.  Because LinkedIn is not the forum for that.  And I appreciate that.  On Saturday I finally had a memorial for my mother.  It has been a hard 2 months both personally and professionally.  And as an only child it’s alway difficult to ask others for help.

  So one has to ask themselves.  What is your purpose?  I spent the last few years focused on my mother’s care.  But where do we go from here?

 I will say this.  I declare war on cancer.  As ridiculous as it sounds.  Before I die I want every cancer clinic shut down.  And every cancer surgeon, doctor, and specialist unemoloyed.   I want the idea of cancer to be as inconsequential as as the DoDo bird or a laser disc.  I want cancer to be the blockbuster of the 21st century.

 Fortunes has lead me to study neural networks and distributed computing the last 10 years.  So there has to be some way to use my skillset to come up with something.  I do know this is what my life will be from here on out.

  I’m no data scientist or biologist.  But I do know that technology is the way.  And i like to solve hard problems.

Most people who know me know that I really love distributed systems.  It’s a passion of mind.  Data problems are just so intriguing.  Especially in how you manage state across a cluster.  It’s probably why I have come to really like or at least appreciate Kafka and Kubernetes as products.

  I’m an admitted database junky.  But I’ve been more concerned about the implementation of database engines than the database utility itself.  I spent the last year studying the source code of key value stores like levelDB, badger, and RocksDB.  Which are the storage engines for Consul, Bitcoin, etc.

  I know my focus should be on building the latest social media network, or video streaming service.  But sometimes as a geek I can’t help myself

I think there needs to be a differentiation between blockchain and cryptocurrency.   I think cryptocurrency has done a lot of harm to the integrity of blockchain development in general.  To the point where people don’t think blockchain development is very useful.

  The reality is the concept of immutability is huge.  It has so much utility in privacy, auditing, and transparency.   It also is key in what I would coin digital “archaeology”.  The ability to have the immutable web is really really important and blockchain helps us achieve this.

  Decentralization is still an area of research in computer science.  Remember that the Byzantine  General problem can’t full be solved without a number of trade offs. So there is still plenty of room for innovation here

I’ve been familiarizing myself with consensus algorithms for the last few years.   I think they’re more important now than ever before.  As we rely on distributed systems for our daily lives it is important to understand how computer science is providing answers to these problems.

I’ve started messing around with Hashicorp GoLang Raft library.   But I think it may be worth it to implement my own version for scratch whenever I find the time

https://lnkd.in/gPuuNpBk

Unfortunately after 4 years of fighting.  My mother lost her battle to cancer last Thursday.   My mother was laid off from a bear 25 year career at TWA in 1995.  And her layoff made her get into computers.  And she encouraged me to learn them shortly after.  I would go on to make a long career in tech.

  She wasn’t just a parent but she was a best friend and a mentor.  She will definitely be missed.

description: I usually work with realtime processing and monitoring so I totally agree witht the idea of notifying as a service. I personally leverage the advantages of RabbitMQ, MinimalAPI and SignalR to get my work done. Distributed scalable processing is also another interesting place to put the notifying on.

My latest pet project to play with Go and LLM models.

The idea of this project is to summarize an multi chapter document structured by chapter numbers, title and content by using LLM services/frameworks like OpenAI (key required) or Ollama(yes, if you've already installed Ollama locally then it's total FREE to use with Mistral model)

I designed to break each chapter in to chunks combines with a struct to store the info of title, and content so that can provide  a better prompt than send the entire document to LLL models.

This project has also covered the basic ideas of Golang such as using environment settings, concurrency with waitgroup and pointers.

I am refactoring this project to modulize my code for reusable purposes. Also trying to move it into API (with Gin?) and put some configs to actively manage requests to LLM services.

I want to share with you an amazing resource that I found on GitHub through a reference post on LinkedIn. It’s a code repository for the book The Azure Cloud Native Architecture Mapbook, published by Packt📚

This book is a must-read for anyone who wants to learn how to design and implement cloud-native solutions using Azure. 🚀 It covers topics such as infrastructure, application, data, and security architecture, as well as cloud-native concepts, microservices, and service mesh technologies. 🙌

The code repository contains the code files for each chapter of the book, as well as PDF files with architecture maps that illustrate the key concepts and best practices. 🗺️ You can download them and follow along with the book, or use them as a reference for your own projects. 💯

If you are interested in this book, you can get your copy today from Packt’s website for free. 😊 And if you like it, don’t forget to share this post with your network. 🌟

All links in comments.

I hope you find this resource useful and inspiring. Let me know what you think in the comments. Happy learning! 😄

description:
I experimented with Golang goroutines and concurrency features by building a load balancer using Go and a round-robin algorithm. The client requests a URL from the load balancer via the terminal, and the request is routed to an available server to serve the requested URL. In response, the URL is opened in the client's default browser, supporting both Linux and Windows. The load balancer manages three servers to handle client requests.

learnt and implemented concurrency control and goroutines in Go using semaphores and by creating Go channels for server and client URL responses.

Github - https://lnkd.in/gFR8PSDN

`npx create-react-tailwindcss <project-name>`.

Our team, consisting of DILER KHAN .R. BIRADAR , Abhishek Deshpande and myself, developed a RESTful API using FastAPI in Python 

This API serves as a convenient source for general knowledge-related questions, readily accessible and integrable into quiz applications. Utilizing an Excel file as our data source, we harnessed the power of Pandas for seamless data manipulation. Handling GET and POST requests, we employed UVICORN for local asynchronous server management. 

Our API delivers JSON-formatted responses and incorporates HTTPException handling for any erroneous requests. This project stands as an entry point to Python, leveraging the fundamental knowledge gained from the Python fundamentals workshop conducted at my college, guided by the insightful teachings of Akshay Kumar U 

The below video demonstrates the api working in Uvicorn local server as

 endpoints
/questions - for all questions
/questions/numsofquestions?limit=(no_of_questions)

description:
"Coloca isso num json ou em .env"
- Dev junior que nunca passou pela dor de armazenar configuração de usuário em app

#Domingou aqui e eu quis trazer esse conteúdo pra quem tem interesse em fazer app ou utilitário de desktop usando arquivos de configuração de usuário.

Cada sistema operacional possui uma estrutura recomendada para armazenar informações no seu app.

O legal de #Golang é que o módulo os já facilita sua vida fornecendo um shortcut para o path desse diretório de acordo com o sistema.

E como todo código #Golang é superficial de entender e reimplementar isso em outras plataformas, legal né?

É só isso por hoje, bom final de final de semana e nos vemos por aqui...

E vamos de novo desafio , como falei mais cedo , hoje foi meu primeiro dia na Global Hitss

E vamos lá...

#soutech
#souhitss
#sougptw

#Segundou como?

Gostaria de compartilhar que estou começando em um novo cargo de Analista de sistema na GLOBAL HITSS 

Hoje é meu primeiro dia, nesse novo desafio!

Eu to vendo muita gente comemorar isso aqui....

Como pessoa que venceu a Gupy duas vezes vou deixar o meu relato....

A plataforma nâo é boa nem ruim, é irrelevante na real, não vejo muita diferenca em relação as demais opções no mercado, talvez seja um pouco melhor por ser mais customizavél os processos seletivos?

A reclamaçâo de todos:

- Processos muito longos
- Vagas fantasma
- Falta de retorno
- Exclusão sumária por AST e afins.

São coisas que não tem haver com a plataforma, não importa pra onde migrem, se o proceaso seletivo é uma droga, sair da plataforma é fazer valher o ditado. Mesmo lixo , caçamba diferente.

Sobre uso de AST e IA, me desvulpe te decepcionar jovem Padawan, mas os processoa seletivos são excludentes de propósito. A culpa não é da IA , é do status quo do mercado no geral, ta dificil pra iniciante poia o momento é de platô, vivemos uma bolha desde 2010, por sorte a pandemia controlou o estouro dela.

Entâo se o proceaso está difícil, tá ruim se recolocar, não é a plataforma X ou Y que está fazendo isso, sâo os contratantes, afinal o que seria do mercado de trabalho sem o desemprego....

"Em golang você fica usando toda hora if err != nil...."
- Dev junior que acha que try catch resolve algum problema



Esses últimos dias estava brincando e experimentando formas novas de fazer o vagabot (nome ainda sendo trabalhado), e percebi que a versão que fiz em #python me obriga a tratar mais erros se comparada a mesma funcionalidade em #elixir e #golang, o motivo disso é a diferença de tratamento de erros nesses ambientes.

Em #python temos o conceito de try Exception , onde podemos criar fluxos de execução conforme tipos de erro, assim somos influenciados a criar classes de erro para situações específicas de erros em nossas bibliotecas e tratar esses erros conforme esses tipos, esse formato não é tão determinístico, pois você tem que supor e "adivinhar" quais erros cada parte de seu código pode causar.

Em #golang temos o outro extremo, onde erros são obrigatoriamente tratados como valores, ou iremos causar um panic em nossas aplicações (if crash, let crash), o interessante disso é que ao consumir bibliotecas não  precisamos "adivinhar" quando um erro irá ocorrer, o mesmo é retornado por uma função no padrão (*Result, error), assim para fazer o caminho feliz , não precisamos saber qual erro ocorreu, apenas validar o que fazer se houve erro ou sucesso. Como erros são tratados como valores, os desenvolvedores podem ignorar, mas na maioria dos casos não vão se deparar com erros "surpresas" ou o famoso "põe tudo no try/catch"

Já #Elixir possui ambas as possibilidades, podendo lançar exceções e fazer tratamentos com try/do, tanto quanto usar pattern match para em caso de erro retornar uma tupla com {:eror, reason}, mas existe uma convenção para coisas que sejam funções que lancem essas exceções anônimas, se usa um ! no final do nome da função, assim assume-se que em caso de erro essa função não teria retorno, apenas explodiria uma exceção,

Eu particularmente consigo desenvolver nos 3 modos, mas como dev preguiçoso , sou mais inclinado a usar o modelo do #golang

Coloquei aqui em baixo trechos de código da implementação de login do vagabot usando #Elixir, #Golang e #Python para verem a diferença.

Lembrando que a implementação em python eu separei em duas classes e tem uma feature a mais, mas mesmo assim o volume de código escrito e tratamento de erro é maior

Mas e você , o que acha? Deixe sua pill sobre error handing nos comentários

#Python
#Elixir
#Golang
#CodeInFriday

Isso mesmo que você leu, não é #FakeNews ou Venda de curso, sou eu mesmo cagando regra para como você deve usar seu navegador.

Esse software que temos em todos os dispositivos, fazem mais do que deviam, repare que é um programa que tem:
- Acesso á FileSystem;
- Acesso á rede;
- Acesso á GPU
- Acesso a devices como câmera e microfone

Se eu fosse uma pessoa mal intencionada a primeira ferramenta que eu tentaria obter acesso seria o navegador.

Então aqui vai algumas dicas de como ficar menos vulnerável ao usar essa caixa de pandora. 

Seu navegador deve estar em "sandbox", ele não deve lembrar de nada, não deve fazer nada automaticamente, exceto quando você explicitamente libere. 

Por isso que ao fechar o seu navegador deve:
- Apagar o seu histórico de acessos e downlaods
- Apagar TODOS os cookies e informações em localstorage
- Retornar todas as permissões de acesso a hardware para o padrão de perguntar antes de usar

Ah e nada de usar gestão de senhas e armazenar cartão de crédito nos seus navegadores, não necessariamente por segurança mas por conveniência, esse tipo de coisa deve estar em ferramentas externas como #Bitwarden e #ProtonPass para que possa ser usada independente de navegador ou plataforma de sistema operacional.

Dos navegadores que eu já usei , #Firefox, #LibreWolf e #Brave são os que tornam essa tarefa de navegador sandbox mais simples de se configurar.

E assim meus amigos, vocês diminuem o que chamamos de "surpeficie de contato"

"O Melhor Teste é Aquele Feito em Produção"
- Dev sem noção que vai ficar trabalhando até tarde para corrigir um if. 🤦‍♂️



Amigos, testes são um negócio complicado. Já passei por situações em que reclamaram que eu escrevo “testes demais” e outras em que disseram que escrevi “testes de menos”. Mas não basta apenas escrever testes; seguir #TDD (Desenvolvimento Orientado a Testes) não garante nada se os testes não tiverem propósito. Afinal, ter 80% de cobertura de testes não garante que os 20% não cobertos não possam causar uma falha grave e irreversível em produção.

Para testar com propósito, é necessário entender também como funcionam suas ferramentas. No mundo #Python, a biblioteca mais usada é o #pytest. Essa maravilhosa biblioteca possui inúmeras features e integrações, sendo a principal delas a definição de fixtures.

Fixtures são estados compartilhados entre testes, algo um tanto estranho de se ouvir quando se fala em testes e #Python na mesma frase. 😄

Escrevi um post mostrando um pouquinho de como usar essas fixtures a nosso favor. Se você quer aprofundar seus conhecimentos sobre o pytest, confira o guia prático que preparei:
https://lnkd.in/dH88RC-N

Lembre-se: testes bem escritos e com propósito são essenciais para garantir a qualidade do seu código em produção. Vamos testar com sabedoria! 🚀
Espero que goste!

E não, funcionar em produção não é o melhor teste , é só uma forma de ter dor de cabeça e retrabalho.

Fale bem, fale mal, mas fale de #dataclass 🐍

Introduzidas na versão 3.7 do Python na PEP 557 (https://lnkd.in/dbsY64xE), as #dataclass nos permitem criar estruturas de dados "flat" sem precisar de todo aquele código boilerplate para reproduzir o comportamento semelhante a structs de C em classes.

Uma das features que eu mais gosto é a capacidade de criar dados imutáveis com campos bem definidos e valores padrão. 

Além disso, as dataclass possuem variáveis especiais em seus construtores que permitem adicionar automaticamente alias para suporte a ordenação e comparação, facilitando o uso em condicionais.

Vantagens das #dataclass:

- Menos Código Boilerplate: Não é mais necessário escrever manualmente métodos comuns como __init__ e __repr__.

- Legibilidade: O código é mais limpo e fácil de ler, focando no que realmente importa - os dados.

- Imutabilidade: Com a opção frozen=True, você pode criar objetos imutáveis, semelhantes a tuplas.

- Comparação Fácil: As #dataclass automaticamente implementam métodos de comparação, como __eq__.

- Herdabilidade: As #dataclass suportam herança, permitindo criar hierarquias de classes (use com moderação).

- Métodos Customizados: Você ainda pode adicionar métodos personalizados dentro de uma #dataclass.

- Campos com Valores Padrão: Utilize field(default=valor) para definir valores padrão.

Cenários Ideais para Uso de #dataclass:

- Modelagem de Dados Rápida e Independente: Permite definir dados de forma simples em uma estrutura flat sem se comprometer com bibliotecas externas como ORM's.

- Configurações e Parâmetros: Para armazenar configurações ou parâmetros de forma estruturada.

- Retornos de API: Estruturar a resposta de uma API torna-se mais fácil e organizado.

Além disso, podemos usar #dataclass em conjunto com ferramentas como #mypy para detecção de inferência de tipo em código fonte, permitindo validar erros de tipagem em processos de CI/CD e evitando subir código falho em produção.

Experimente integrar as dataclass em seus projetos Python e veja a diferença! 🚀

Compartilhe sua experiência com #dataclass nos comentários! #Python #Desenvolvimento #BoilerplateFree #CleanCode

"Prefiro não usar o #Debian stable devido às suas aplicações 'desatualizadas'."
- Usuário de linux que nunca leu a wiki e não sabe o que está perdendo.

Antes de tudo, é importante esclarecer que o #Debian GNU/Linux, em sua versão estável, tende a manter pacotes com versões mais antigas para garantir uma estabilidade robusta. No entanto, isso não significa que você esteja preso a essas versões. Uma solução inteligente para esse dilema são os #backports.

Os #backports permitem que você atualize pacotes específicos sem comprometer a estabilidade geral do sistema. Não apenas no #Debian, mas em outras distribuições Linux, essa prática é comum e extremamente útil.

Basicamente, os #backports trazem atualizações de pacotes do #Debian testing e #Debian unstable para a versão estável, oferecendo pequenas correções ou atualizações de segurança. Isso garante que você possa desfrutar das últimas funcionalidades sem sacrificar a estabilidade.

Mas como fazer isso na prática?

Primeiro, é necessário adicionar os repositórios de #backport à sua configuração de atualização. Isso pode ser feito facilmente através da ferramenta gráfica de atualização ou editando diretamente o arquivo sources.list em /etc/apt/sources.list. Lembre-se de incluir as flags necessárias para garantir o acesso a todos os tipos de pacotes, incluindo aqueles que podem estar sob licenças não livres.

Uma vez configurado, você pode instalar os pacotes desejados utilizando o comando apt install, acrescentando a flag -t <nome_do_repositório> para especificar de qual repositório você deseja instalar. Por exemplo, se quiser instalar o Cockpit em seu sistema a partir do repositório #backport, basta digitar apt -t bookworm-backports install cockpit.

Para mais informações detalhadas sobre como utilizar os #backports, recomendo consultar a Wiki do #Debian:

https://lnkd.in/dYzahf83

Dessa forma, você pode desfrutar do melhor dos dois mundos: a estabilidade do Debian stable com as atualizações mais recentes dos seus aplicativos favoritos. Experimente e descubra todo o potencial que o Debian tem a oferecer! 🐧✨ #Debian #Linux #Backports #EstabilidadeEVersatilidade

Tá e como funciona essa jorça?

Existem dois comandos implementados, um que busca postagens que supostamente são sobre vagas (De acordo com a query ) e outro comando pega essas postagens da base local gerada (sqlite) e sai comentando nessas postagens com a mensagem de sua escolha

Ainda falta muito refinamento, ajuste de features e implementações de edge cases como evitar postagens com comentários bloqueados, fora algumas limitações....

Pretendo ir atualizando este projeto ao longo do tempo e ver no que dá....
